title: Crowdfunding platform quits green sector
text:
Renewables crowdfunding in doubt as lending platform quits sector Naomi Rovnick ©Bloomberg 
The future of crowdfunding for renewables projects has been thrown into question after a prominent business closed its door to new green energy loans following cutbacks in government support for the sector. 
Julia Groves, chair of the UK Crowd Funding Association, has left her role as chief executive of Trillion Fund after it ceased its main activity as a crowdfunding and lending platform for renewables businesses last month. More Boardroom trades, October 10 
Trillion, which says it now plans to offer crowdfunding services in other sectors, is the latest business affected by policy moves that included the scrapping of a climate change tax exemption and a decision to end subsidies for onshore wind power. 
This month, two UK green energy companies went into administration , with their failures being widely blamed on government policy. 
“When the government announced it was withdrawing so much of the support for smaller-scale projects, that rocked investors’ confidence and made the viability of such projects very uncertain,” Ms Groves said. 
Trillion has raised loans for two onshore wind energy projects, including one where it promised 7 per cent fixed interest for three years, that it said had been affected by policy changes. It said on its website that while these projects’ future revenue streams will be slightly reduced, investors “will continue to be paid interest by the borrower and have capital repaid”. 
Despite the high-risk nature of funding start-ups, the UK’s alternative finance industry is growing, with £2.1bn raised so far this year via peer-to-peer lending and crowdfunding, according to data provider AltFi. A report published last year by Cambridge university and Nesta, an innovation charity, also found that 92 per cent of peer-to-peer lenders wanted to support green or renewable products.
